snippet: From the March on Washington to the fast-food strikes, workers have fought for a decent living, but little progress has been made.
abstract: Editorial notes the compelling parallels between the March on Washington and the thousands of fast-food workers in 60 cities who walked off their jobs to demand higher pay and the rights to organize without retaliation; calls for policies to ensure that a large and growing share of rising labor productivity flows to workers, starting with an adequate minimum wage and protections for workers to unionize.
lead_paragraph: From the March on Washington to the fast-food strikes, workers have fought for a decent living, but little progress has been made.
